title: 111_hr767
content: The Act is titled the "National Financial Literacy Act of 2009" and includes provisions for financial literacy programs. Section 804 of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977 is amended to include new subsection (d) regarding Direct Support for Financial Literacy Programs. The Federal financial supervisory agencies will establish standards for eligible programs and procedures for financial institutions to apply for approval as qualified community-based financial literacy programs. The amendment to the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977 includes new subsection (d) on Direct Support for Financial Literacy Programs. Financial institutions must submit reports on their support for financial literacy in the community. Regulations will require a qualified program to be offered by a nonprofit agency and provide education on consumer, economic, and financial matters. The amendment to the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977 introduces new subsection (d) on Direct Support for Financial Literacy Programs. Financial institutions are required to report their support for financial literacy programs in the community, which includes education on consumer, economic, and financial issues such as retirement savings, credit management, and identity theft. Financial institutions can receive credit for supporting qualified community-based financial literacy programs. SEC. 45R. Small businesses can receive a credit against income tax for providing continuing financial education to employees. Small businesses can receive a 35 percent tax credit for offering qualified continuing financial education programs to employees through community-based budget and counseling agencies. Eligible small businesses must provide these programs without charge to qualify for the credit. 501(c)(3) organizations promoting consumer understanding of financial issues, offered to employees with at least 2 weeks of service, with specific monthly hour requirements based on the taxpayer's type. Small Business Definition: A small business is defined as an employer with an average of 2 to 50 employees during the most recent calendar year, and at least 2 employees at the start of the taxable year. Employees expected to be employed on business days in the taxable year are subject to special rules regarding controlled groups and predecessors. Section 280C of the tax code denies double benefits for small businesses providing continuing financial education to employees. Employees expected to work on business days in the taxable year are subject to special rules regarding controlled groups and predecessors. Section 280C of the tax code denies double benefits for small businesses providing continuing financial education to employees, with specific rules outlined for deductions and credits under sections 45R(a) and 38(b) of the Code. Clerical Amendment made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Tax Code. Section 45R allows small businesses to provide financial education to employees. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. Additionally, small businesses and corporations offering financial education to employees receive preference in federal contracts, loans, and other assistance. In federal contracts and assistance, eligible small businesses and corporations with financial education programs for employees receive preference. Eligible small businesses are defined by section 45R(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, while eligible corporations must have 50 or more employees and offer a qualified financial education program. The term "qualified continuing financial education program" is defined in section 45R(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Federal financial or nonfinancial assistance includes all programs and activities covered by Executive Order No. 12549 and procurement programs. The preference required under subsection (a) will be applied starting on January 1, 2010.
